page.title: 12EARLY SETTLEMENTS-ARNCLIFFE
page.content: The remains of an Iron Age Settlement are situated on Blue Scar. Compartments led off two main areas. One is thought to have been a beehive hut with two entrances. The walls were several feet thick. Nearby are several upright stones with holes in, through which, it is said, the sun shines on Midsummers Day. Some of the lower fields in the valley were cultivated by these Iron Age people, their terraces, or lynchets, still showing clearly. Near Arncliffe, at a place called Thornbottoms Barn, there are the remains of a ringwork, similar to those found in Wales. Pottery, charcoal, a knife and a coin from the reign of Emperior Gordianus III (238 AD) were found, suggesting that the site dates from Roman times, and possibly earlier.
